newsitem.title: USA: S&P official calls White House's DC plan "bold".
newsitem.headline: S&P official calls White House's DC plan "bold".

text.p: Bond rating agencies lauded the $3.9 billion federal aid plan announced by the White House on Tuesday for the District of Columbua and said they are eager to see if it survives city and congressional scrutiny.
"It's encouraging that the administration has put forward such bold changes for the District," Parry Young, director of public finance at Standard & Poor's Corp, said in a telephone interview.
If Congress clears the plan, the city's current junk bond rating "could go up," Young said.
"It's a pretty reasonable approach," Barbara Flickinger, assistant director and vice president of public finance at Moody's Investors Service, said.

"Obviously, it needs to be embraced by the city council, D.C. financial control board, and Congress," she said. "(But) if these elements were to be enacted, it does bode well for the credit outlook" for the city, she said.

Flickinger said the plan would do two important things. It would address "structural problems," like the multi-billion-dollar unfunded pension liability, that the city inherited from the U.S. government in the 1970s.
The plan also recognizes that the D.C. economy needs revitalizing over the long, so that city revenues will continue to grow even when D.C.'s control board is dissolved, she said.
D.C. Mayor Marion Barry said, "This will enhance our ability to go to the bond market in 1998 to borrow money" for long term financings like road and bridge repairs.

"Two of the greatest impediments to us having a higher bond rating were the unfunded pension liability and the unpredictable federal payment," he said, referring to a $660 million payment Congress makes annually to the city for the federal government's use of D.C. property.

The President said Congress should assume responsibility for the pension problem and other state-like functions currently handled by D.C. At the same time, Congress should wipe out the $660 million annual payment, the President said.
Under the White House plan, the federal and District governments and the city's control board must hammer out a memorandum of understanding before the plan can be sent to Capitol Hill for review.
